channel.title: Photography on Aliens in the Apple
channel.description: Recent content in Photography on Aliens in the Apple

item.title: Black and white trees
item.description: I love the way leaf-less trees look so stark in black and white. These photos were taken in Prospect Park, Brooklyn a couple of years back. And this one in Lancaster County. March was heralded in by a snowstorm, and it looked like this in front of our house just a couple of weeks ago:

item.title: Beautiful snow
item.description: Last week we had another bit of snow. (That was the snow before today’s snow, and Sunday’s snow, and then the two snows before that.) It seems every time Boston gets a foot or more of snow, we get about 2 or 3 inches.

item.title: A prize-winning photo!
item.description: With such a sensationalist title, you’d think this is something really special, right? Well, not quite! TripAdvisor (where Ben works) had this internal competition over the summer where you could send in a photo with a TripAdvisor fridge magnet on your vehicle, and every week they picked a winner.

item.title: Beautiful berries
item.description: I was washing berries for dessert the other night and just had to stop and marvel that God didn’t just make food useful, He also made it beautiful. And they tasted delicious!

item.title: Roadtrip: Lone Pine
item.description: The next stop couldn’t have been more different from Las Vegas. Tranquil, rural, isolated, pretty much nobody around, right in nature, and no electricity! We stayed the night in a little cabin/tent outside a small town called Lone Pine, between the Death Valley and the Sierra Nevada Mountains.

item.title: Garden of the Gods at sunrise
item.description: When we were visiting the Boonzaaijers’ in Colorado Springs, I decided to get up early one morning to go and take some photos of the Garden of the Gods. I had heard that it was particularly beautiful at sunrise, so I got up at 5am and headed on down there, just as the sky was changing colour.

item.title: Visit to the Boonzaaijers’
item.description: So, getting around to posting these last roadtrip posts have crawled to a terribly slow pace, but I’m determined to finish them up. When I get to that point, I’ll evaluate whether or not I keep AliensInTheApple going, or change its name, or just say “So long, and thanks for all the fish.

item.title: Wildflowers
item.description: I snapped these little beauties on the Davys’ farm near Darfield. Anyone know what they’re called?

item.title: Cool wood grain
item.description: I saw this beam at the farm we stayed at when we took Lizel to Lancaster County, and really liked the way the wood grain showed up on it.

item.title: Special time with Pappa
item.description: I think the Pennsylvanian countryside is just so beautiful. It seems very peaceful to me, perhaps because I’m usually on holiday when I’m there. When we took Lizel there when she visited, Marica stayed with dear friends who took her to a ballet concert, so Esther got to be the only child for a weekend.

item.title: My daddy is stronger than your daddy
item.description: I know I’m thoroughly biased, but this photo just melts my heart. Our girls sure are blessed to have such a wonderful daddy.

item.title: Droplets
item.description: I visited Margaret and her family on a drizzly Sunday afternoon in January, and just had to take a photo of this plant in her garden. The water droplets seemed to just stick to it in such a pretty way!

item.title: Lovely lavender, and a bee to boot
item.description: I’ve got so many photos I’d like to share from my time in New Zealand, but time is eluding me. The photos in the post today were taken in Christchurch, in the new Cashel Mall where they have a mall made out of shipping containers that have been refurbished, and looks way better than it sounds.

item.title: Yellow Orchid
item.description: I took this photo at the Eshelmans’ place over Christmas time. What a cheery little yellow fellow!

item.title: Black and white, day 16
item.description: Today is the last day of the black and white series. Thanks for bearing with me. I hope you’re not all now sick and tired of black and white photographs — I love them! Today’s photos are from when Ben and Marica attended the Nutcracker ballet, December 2011.

item.title: Black and white, day 6
item.description: A statue of The Signer in Philadelphia. This photo is significant, because today a man from Philadelphia is signing a very special contract with a very special lady in Christchurch. Yes, today Jeremy and Lillian are getting married!

item.description: A very interesting tree by Central Park, just opposite the Museum of Natural History.

item.title: Bygone days; black and white day 1
item.description: To start off the black and white series while I’m away, I thought I’d introduce you to Planter. He lives in the Eshelmans’ neighbors’ yard who had the lovely little thing refurbished all nice and new, parked it beside the house and haven’t touched it for about 15 years.

item.title: This little piggy
item.description: A black and white shot of Esther’s little feet, shortly before her 2nd birthday. Happy New Year, everyone! We hope that the new year will be a blessed one.

item.title: Lovely hair
item.description: A while back we girls had a fun afternoon of doing each other’s hair. I made Marica’s hair into a triple braid. She was studiously doing her schoolwork while I took photos of her hair!

item.title: Some nature shots from the Adirondacks
item.description: During our time in the Adirondacks it rained most of the time, except for our first afternoon there. There were some breaks in the rain, though, and I took my chances to go outside and take some ‘nature shots’.

item.title: Some cool photos of the Guggenheim
item.description: I don’t really care for modern art much, so I’ve never felt a deep desire to go look at what’s inside the Guggenheim museum (I can get my fill at the Met by glimpsing at the modern art section when I walk past there to get to the European sculptures).

item.title: Night
item.description: “Why are you downcast, O my soul? Why so disturbed within me?” Ps 43:5 That’s what this sculpture by Aristide Maillol brought to mind when I saw it at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The artist did an amazing job — it was as if everything about her just felt so sad.

item.title: Where there’s a will, there’s a way
item.description: As shown by this very stubborn plant determined to grow on a church steeple in Baltimore.

item.title: Accidental coolness
item.description: When I was driving through Philly with Margaret, I was just happily snapping pictures of stuff out of the car while we were driving. I happened to take this picture of a city centre sculpture and when I went through the photos afterwards I saw how perfectly (total fluke) the moon was aligned with this thing.

item.title: A pre-engagement visit
item.description: Now that you all know that Lillian and Jeremy are engaged, we can all happily say “Hooray!”. Lillian was here for a very short visit (just under 2 weeks) and flew into JFK, so we got the privilege of hosting the two of them for a few nights before they went off to Philadelphia to go get engaged.

item.title: Taking kids on a photo shoot can be interesting
item.description: And also pretty fun. Perhaps “photo shoot” is too formal a title for what we did with Jeremy and Lillian, but I still tried to get a heap of photos while at the same time trying to keep an eye on two speedy escape artists.

item.title: Now for the black and white engagement pics
item.description: As I said earlier, my previous post kept freezing up because I had too many photos in there, so I instead made the first post the colour post and this one the black&white post. I personally often prefer black and white, so this was fun for me.

item.title: The last one bites the dust
item.description: But that makes it sound like it’s a bad thing when it is indeed a very happy thing — the last of 8 children getting married. Yes, that’s right, Ben’s little sister, Lillian, is engaged to be married to a certain Mr Jeremy Fisher, uh, I mean Mr Jeremy L Eshelman!

item.title: Perspective
item.description: I like how the composition of this photo turned out: pretty clover in focus and a couple in the background. Some of the clover leaves look like love hearts… It’s kind of sweet. :-)

item.title: Another beautiful zinnia
item.description: It boggles my mind that God would put such intricate beauty into a simple flower… layer upon layer, curly baby petals… in a pot I too often forget to water. But then again, it really shouldn’t surprise me.

item.title: Lorraine, the not-so Divine
item.description: Saw this old building on our way to Jeremy’s place in Philadelphia, and couldn’t help noticing the irony.

item.title: Childlike trust
item.description: Trust is knowing that we are small and God is big and that He will not let us go.

item.title: Photo fun
item.description: The outside of our house at the back is painted in a vivid blue. I’ve planted some zinnias in pots, and the colour contrast is great. I had some fun taking photos of a couple of flowers the other day.
